byline.original: By NATHANIEL POPPER and PETER EAVIS

abstract: Regulatory push has caused contraction on Wall Street, where bonuses have shrunken, growth has stalled and business lines have been cut; changes are largely due to strictures requiring banks to hold far more of their capital in reserve, though economic trends and other regulations have also been factor; profits have remained high despite changes, though they are increasingly dependent on cost cutting.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street is in a transformation, as bonuses shrink, revenue growth stalls and business lines are cut, driven primarily by regulatory efforts.

headline.main: New Rules Spur a Humbling Overhaul of Wall St. Banks
headline.print_headline: On Wall St., Rules on Capital Humble Banks and Shrink Pay

snippet: Wall Street is in a transformation, as bonuses shrink, revenue growth stalls and business lines are cut, driven primarily by regulatory efforts.

keywords.value: Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject
